Comment: Note to ignorant Associate Press and the equally ignorant Denver Post Editorial Staff. Micronesia isn't a country. Micronesia is a sub-geographic area in the Western Pacific. The U.S. Territory of Guam is part of Micronesia.  The Federated States of Micronesia are comprised of Yap, Chuuk, Pohnpei, and Kosrae. 

Moreover, it's the Republic of Palau. It's not a group of islands. It's a sovereign nation. Palau gained its independence on October 1, 1994. Some Americans would recognize the ferocious WWII Pacific battle of Peleliu. Peleliu is one of the states of Palau. When you visit Peleliu, you'll see beautiful memorials to the 2k+ U.S. Marines, Navy, and Army service members who were killed. You'll also see beautiful memorials to the 10k+ Japanese who died in the battle. Palau lost 10% of its population to WWII. Yet the Palauans respect the dead from both sides despite the immense tragedy. If they were Americans, they'd already be tearing down the memorials to the dead.

Comment: The basic problem with a Universal income is macro economic. If everyone is provided an additional means of consumption, and the amount of goods to consume doesn't increase, prices will simply rise to eliminate the imbalance. This is not about soaking the 1%, it's about stoking price inflation, which typically hurts people on a fixed income more than those who see routine raises. It explains why all of the proponents of these ideas, rich or poor, are invariably young and insensitive to those in our society who have earned a small stipend that they must rely on into their "golden years".

Comment: Rent control are not fair to landlords of condo units, especially those built pre-1991. Unlike apartment buildings, condo buildings are incorporated and have an elected Board of Directors. Every year the Board develops a budget and determines how much the maintenance fees need to be increased to cover costs. From my experience this increase ranges from 1.5% to 4%, with increases being higher for older buildings that typically need more maintenance. If you also add on the property tax increases enacted by Council, a landlord's costs can increase between 2.8% and 5.3% (this assumes a property tax increase of 1.3%).

For condo units built pre-1991, the rent guidelines only allow a rent increase of between 1.5% and 2%. This means that landlords of these units are more than likely not able to recoup a significant portion of the increased costs, which is not fair or equitable. Landlords should be able increase rent by the same increase to maintenance fees and property taxes.

Comment: Sorry. You are mistaken.

An Oxford comma is defined as: "a comma used after the penultimate item in a list of three or more items, before ‘and’ or ‘or’ (e.g., an Italian painter, sculptor, and architect )."

A comma splice is the use of a comma to join two independent clauses into a run-on sentence which is what you did.

Comment: Glare we've all seen from oncoming HID equipped vehicles is much more hazardous because it introduces an added distraction I'd call the "flicker effect," far more prevalent than the soft-edged lighting that characterized the older technology sealed beam headlamps.  Now, if it were indeed possible to confine such lighting to JUST where it's needed, namely the road, then there would be little complaint.  The problem confronting us is that roads are seldom perfectly straight and especially here in Hawaii, rarely smooth and level.  There is no way to prevent excessive overspill of headlight beams on curved roads unless the predictive GPS-enabled headlight positioning fix becomes a cheap and standard equipment reality someday.  (And yes, there is old-school technology that links headlight aim with a car's steering wheel position, but this is in no way "predictive" in any useful sense and again, does not consider the slope of the road).

Biasing headlights to aim high is "Hawaii Style" too.

Comment: On the origin of "kek:" the term comes from World of Warcraft, a hugely popular online game in the mid to late 2000s and still popular today. There were two warring factions: the Alliance and the Horde. When in proximity to one another, the speech of one faction could be seen, but not understood, by the other. When a horde player said LOL, it would appear to an Alliance member as "KEK." Basically, it is the same as LOL, but was an in-joke for those that played the game, and for internet-savvy people in general. Its meaning has drifted, but that's a pretty easy piece of research that's notably absent from this article.

Comment: Dyslexia is a type of learning disability. Whether a child is designated with a learning disability or dyslexia matters not as long as the assessement outlines their strengths and needs and makes suggestions for accommodations and interventions.
Assessment may not take place until 3rd grade, but that does not preclude reading interventions.
Canada consistenly ranks in the top 5 countries in terms of reading skills. In the most recent report by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (2016), we ranked 3rd. The United States ranked 24th, so I hardly think we should be emulating their system.
Of course there are inevitably children whose reading difficulties are not recognized early, and others who do not receive the support they need. Our system is not perfect and we need to always aim to improve. And even when high quality interventions are in place, they take time and a lot of effort on the part of the student. An assessment is no quick fix.

Comment: The Polish bishop Wesolowski did go through a canonical trial in the Vatican, which resulted in his laicization in June 2014 - based on canon law.  The trial that was pending at the time of his death was a criminal trial, under Vatican City State criminal law (not canon law), for child molestation and possession of child pornography.  The Vatican argued at the time that Wesolowski could not be tried for child molestation in either the Dominican Republic or his native Poland because, at the time of the criminal behavior in question, he was a Vatican diplomat and subject only to the law of the Vatican City State.

Presumably Apuron in Guam cannot be considered an employee of the Vatican City State, and thus the Vatican proceeding will likely be a canon-law trial probably resulting in laicization.  If there's to be any criminal trial in the Apuron matter, I'd guess that will be up to the government of Guam.  I don't think that the changes implemented by Francis cover criminal action.

-  people try to physically prevent a speaker from entering the venue?
-  people threaten the venue owner with potential violence if the speaker is allowed in their venue?
-  people blow loud whistles or air horns while the speaker is trying to speak?
- people dress to hide their identity, then riot and throw fire bombs to try and prevent a speaker from speaking?

Comment: The average suppression level, according to independent tests done on a variety of commercially available suppressors, is around 30 dB, which is around the same reduction level of typical ear protection gear often used when firing guns.

However, for most commercially available fire arms and cartridges, this ends up only reducing the noise level to somewhere in the range of 130-150-ish dB for a supersonic cartridge and 117-130-ish dB for a subsonic cartridge. For reference on just how loud that is, an ambulance or police siren is typically between 100-140 dB. 

So if we imagine the shooter had a silencer, the difference in carnage wouldn't likely have been effected.

Comment: Continued. "There were no differences between nonusers and daily users in the specific regions of interest [nucleus accumbens, amygdala, hippocampus, and the cerebellum--areas high in cannabis receptors]. Comment: This op-ed is misleading in several ways. First, it’s not just profit-driven developers that are not in favor: apparently very few of the local well-known environmental groups, sustainability organizations, or green building organizations have endorsed it. Second, it’s not just 20% of roof space, it’s 20-60%, a big difference. Third, you can’t actually get a solar waiver: as written, the ordinance requires that you still dedicate 30% of your required area to a green roof even if you do solar. Fourth, Toronto and San Francisco have very different climates/weather than we do here. Our plants, without a ton of water, are brown not green in the heat of summer and the dead of winter. We’re already piping in water from other parts of the state to fix shortages. Even Denver Water didn’t come out in favor.

Comment: Highway 126 is a state highway. I have long advocated for a four-lane US highway between the Willamette Valley and central Oregon, but that isn't likely to happen, ever. Comment: At the college I teach at part-time instructors are making between $90 to $110 per teaching hour in a full-time program. When all the prepping, marking, meetings, and email communication with the students is added, it works out to about $35 an hour for actual time spent. At $35 per teaching hour, you would be making less than minimum wage based on total hours worked. Not many qualified people would want to do that. Part-timers in our program are hired based on their real world industry experience, and many are happy to teach a few hours a week, as they usually have other freelance work. This is good for the students as the information they receive is current. You are right about the instructors not receiving much support to meet the needs of the individual students, including those students with accommodations, even though administration costs have increased substantially.

Comment: People often look at home/road splits and assume that the road splits are a players's "true" stats, and anything they do above that at home is added by their home park. For most teams that's true, but there is mounting evidence that for Rockies players, playing half their games at high altitude actually makes their road stats worse than if they played for any other team. So while Helton's career home stats of .345/.442/.607 are certainly not a true indicator of his ability, his .287/.386/.470 road split is just as suspect. So for Rockies players, their true stats are somewhere in the middle, and Helton's overall numbers are probably pretty close to what he would have done as a member of any other team.

The Rockies really should start some sort of campaign educating baseball writers and fans of how Coors Field really works and build some support for guys like Helton and Walker. If guys like those two don't make it into the hall, I have to wonder if ANY Rockies player has a chance?

Comment: Thanks for the report, I hadn't seen it. There are two points I would raise from said Australian experience.

"Projects not addressing long-term water shortages: Numerous local and international
case studies show that developing desalination as an emergency drought response can lead to significant unintended political and debt consequences. Unless a desalination project addresses a baseline water shortage in the longer term as part of a water supply mix, there is bound to be an element of demand-side risk. When desalination is used as a drought response in a region which is not perennially dry, the demand-side risk is especially acute."

This is certainly not the case in the Cape, where both climate and population problems mean there is likely to be a permanent drought situation.

France on the other hand uses a two round FPTP system (no party lists and  only one member per constituency like Canada). There the right wing was emphatically defeated and Macron's government was up and running in a week or so after the final round.

Comment: Here is another viewpoint for those who love free markets in education.  Those districts that have better working conditions and better pay for Front Range teachers attract better (i.e. more credentialed and more experienced) teachers than districts that do not offer these advantages.  All of the Colorado districts that have these positive features also have unions.  Since teachers will migrate in droves to settings with better conditions (see the case of Douglas County), the better school districts set the price for all the districts.  Teacher pay is improved from even SOME of the school districts having unions.  Douglas County School District has put itself in the hole by hundreds of million of dollars in teacher salaries that it will have to pony up from local funds in order to restore the district to functionality.  And it did much of this so that it could stop negotiating with a pretty mild teachers' association.  That was a steep price to pay for ideology.

WASHINGTON RCW 46.37.390
Mufflers required—Smoke and air contaminant standards—Definitions—Penalty, exception.
(1) Every motor vehicle shall at all times be equipped with a muffler in good working order and in constant operation to prevent excessive or unusual noise, and no person shall use a muffler cut-out, bypass, or similar device upon a motor vehicle on a highway.
(3) No person shall modify the exhaust system of a motor vehicle in a manner which will amplify or increase the noise emitted by the engine of such vehicle above that emitted by the muffler originally installed on the vehicle, and it shall be unlawful for any person to operate a motor vehicle not equipped as required by this subsection, or which has been amplified as prohibited by this subsection. 

Really Tristan?

1) 700 proposals over 200 years without a successful amendment. That certainly rises to the "Time Tested" level of validation, particularly when viewed over so many generations.

Look, if you're going a make a huge deal about Russia taking back Crimea, which it owned for over two hundred years, until 1991, shouldn't you applaud Trump's refusing to kowtow to China's demand that we pretend that Taiwan, a functioning democracy with a GDP per capita that is higher than Canada's (!), does not exist? Comment: Is Alaska and are Alaska Natives better off as part of the United States?  If the answer to that question is yes, then a statue honoring the man who made it possible seems fitting. And while Natives undoubtedly suffered from racial discrimination over the years, and in some instances still do, they have also benefitted from laws that recognize their rights (ANCSA) and programs enacted to meet their needs -- Native hospitals and investments in village schools, water and sewer systems.   Bennie Benson, a Native, designed the state flag. It should also be noted that the Alaska purchase was a small part of Seward's career which is distinguished by his lifelong efforts to eradicate the oppression of blacks (slavery) and his major role in preserving the nation during the Civil War.  On balance, I think he deserves a statute. But if denied, the next time I visit Alaska I can travel to Seward on July 4.

Comment: The State of Alaska is being gutted piece by piece. The Alaska Mental Health Trust, under Jeff Jesse's leadership, has been a shining light in the oncoming darkness. Years ago I worked for a nonprofit agency that turned my division over to an accountant with no mental health experience. It took this person less than a year, before she was replaced, before she almost destroyed the agency. If they hire an individual with "business and natural resource experience" I fear the same will happen to the Trust. Yes we need to raise money to deal with the huge budget deficit. Comment: I'm visiting in coastal Washington State for the first time in a few years, and buying groceries and household items. I've definitely noticed their shopping bag tax - apparently on both plastic and large paper - frankly I've been too busy to glean the tax particulars -- but I have observed the natural economic behavior changes among my fellow shoppers!      Observations?  First,  more people than in Anchorage are bringing their own bags with them - The dime-per-bag levy HAS -at least from my personal observations -significantly reduced Washingtonians' consumption of plastic - and paper - bags among shoppers. Comment: The political structure of postmodernism shows that the power dynamics that feed into the realm of the political differ from those of modern politics. Today, the General Will (political narrative) originates in the power dynamics found between you and those you interact with in the Digital Estate. This is called Digital Association. 

In digital association, there exists the realm of the political, and it is constructed through your interactions with others in the form of tweets, emails, favorite Facebook posts, videos watched etc. This postmodern individual political narrative is neither true of false. It is a narrative that is constantly under construction and interpretation. 

Belief is suspended until that time in which you have to act.

Since we still use a modern political system of representation with political parties formed and constrained by ideology, there is this split between a postmodern individual narrative (bottom up) and the modern political narrative (top down).

Comment: Another option would for each state to require that its electoral votes would go proportionally to the popular vote in that state so that multiple candidates could win at least some of a state's electoral votes.  That would get rid of the winner-takes-all nonsense and shift the campaigns away from focusing entirely on a tiny handful of 'battleground' states to having to focus on all states.   

Right now a conservative never bothers to campaign in California because there's zero chance of them winning those 55 votes.  But in the proportional system, Trump would have taken about 18 of those votes due to his 32% of the popular vote there.  Conversely, Clinton would have taken 16 of Texas' 36 votes due to her 43% of the vote there.

In this way, every state would be a battleground state and the candidates would be motivated to campaign nationwide rather than just in a half dozen states.  Heck, maybe we'd even see a presidential candidate visit Alaska! (Clinton would have taken 1 of our 3)

Comment: I'm fairly suspicious of this idea.

Seems to me that there's enough crime in Toronto to support five courthouses, both for the reasons given in the article and because the single structure can lead to single-point failure of the entire apparatus, whether the failure is due to natural events, bad design, human intervention by way of protests, etc., and the question of what happens when it's time for the structure to be replaced.

I would prefer a long-term plan whereby a new courthouse is scheduled to be built every twenty years or so, incorporating the lessons learned, new technologies and new procedures developed since the prior construction.

Comment: This article fails to also report the assets/income ratio for our households, which is above 5 times (compared to 1.7 times for the debt/income ratio).

The "housing bubble" is often mentioned as a great risk. But, there are 13.5 million households in Canada; about 9.5 million are home owners, with about half being mortgage free.

Annually, home sales amount to about .5 million, with close to .25 million being first-time buyer transactions.

Thus the housing bubble benefits the 9.5 million households who are home owners, whose equity is rising, regardles of whether or not they have a mortgage; and it hurts the 250,000 first-time buyers, who must find the extra funds to join home ownership (with Vancouver and Toronto being the most challenging places).

 The asset ratio is also high due to the fact that it includes the net present value of pensions, the CPP, OAS, etc. 

Taken account of all that, the risk due to the "high" Canadian household debt level is a lot less than alledged.

Comment: No.  Just no.  You have a full time nanny and a work space that is physically separated from your home?  that's not working from home with kids.  Working from home with kids is having the baby strapped to your chest for a nap while you sit at the computer.  It's balancing your need to finish something with your guilt over letting your kids spend another hour playing video games so you will be able to finish it.  It's never having more than 15 minutes in a row to do anything because 15 minutes is the longest your toddler will ever play with anything by herself.   It's learning how to do 8 hours of work in the 5 hours that your kids spend in school.  

Nothing wrong with having a nanny.  But handing childcare to someone else for 8 hours every day so you can get your work done is *not* working home with kids.

Comment: "Teaching driving has been left up to parents"

That depends on the age of the student.

This past June, my eldest got his instruction permit right after his 15th birthday, since he, his mother, and I want him to get his license as soon as possible. By law, he has to have:
* 30-hour classroom instruction
* 6-hour certified training
* Currently working on (and logging) 50 hours of practice

The 30-hour classroom instruction was required to get his permit before age 15.5 years. The 6-hour behind-the-wheel training will be required to get his license before age 16.5 years.

If we'd waited 6 months, the 30-hour requirement would've been reduced to 4 hours. Then, since he couldn't get his license until age 16.5 (if under age 18, you have to have a permit for at least 12 months), the 6-hour certified training would've gone away.

The 50 hours of practice, logged and signed by a parent, are required to get a license before age 18.

http://www.amren.com/news/2015/07/new-doj-statistics-on-race-and-violent-crime/

This table can be used for a number of interesting calculations. First, we find that during the 2012/2013 period, blacks committed an average of 560,600 violent crimes against whites, whereas whites committed only 99,403 such crimes against blacks. This means blacks were the attackers in 84.9 percent of the violent crimes involving blacks and whites. This figure is consistent with reports from 2008, the last year DOJ released similar statistics. Perhaps not coincidentally, that was the year Mr. Obama was elected president.

Interestingly, we find that violent interracial crime involving blacks and Hispanics occurs in almost exactly the same proportions as black/white crime: Blacks are the attackers 82.5 percent of the time, while Hispanics are attackers only 17.5 percent of the time.

Comment: The long standing rule relating to circumstantial evidence in criminal cases is the rule in Hodge's case. I don't recall the exact words, but the general idea is that before you can convict solely on circumstantial evidence, that evidence must be not only consistent with guilt but inconsistent with any innocent explanation.  In this case, "consent" is a possible innocent explanation.

Government prints money, but doesn't actually create wealth. Comment: "Greens with a mere 16% of the popular vote, now wield a power vastly out of proportion to their percentage of votes."

The Greens are wielding that power in our CURRENT system. 

I note you are conveniently omitting the fact that the Greens got 16.5% of the votes and yet they're getting only 3.5% of the seats. Though they might hold the balance of power, they're still short-changed for representation.

This not a partisan issue.

Federal conservative party in 1993 got ~16% of the votes and wound up with ~1% of the seats. 

The status quo might favor a party I support, but I can't defend that outcome.

And cut the fear mongering: there are plenty of examples of functional democracies that have proportional systems. 

At the provincial and federal level, we very typically have "majority" governance that is secured with <40% of votes. 

The "stability" the present system offers ONLY exists because the system often lets elected officials ignore the voting will of the majority of voters.

Comment: I assume that Henry VIII was talking about the privilege of clergy that entitled them to be tried only in canonical courts and not in the State courts. This was essentially the dispute between Henry II and Thomas A'Beckett, but after the latter's murder, Henry II backed off on his demands. Henry VIII did cut back the privilege but it did not completely disappear in Britain until 1827. The 1532 moment has already happened. In virtually all democratic countries, the civil law takes no notice of canon law - it has as much relevance as the rules of golf, as one Irish judge put it. The exceptions are where the Vatican has entered into Concordats with sympathetic Catholic countries, the most notable of which is Colombia where bishops are above the civil law. Some countries in their civil laws provide for a form of privilege for religious confessions, but that is because as a matter of policy they have decided to include that in their civil laws.

Comment: Nonsense.The classic example is less than 1% of healthcare. Even most ER visits that are appropriate visits are not super time sensitive.You may have that broken ankle and need to go to an ER because you can't get in with an orthopedist right away, but you can still make a choice between the hospital that's ten minutes away and the one that's 15 minutes away. If we had their prices-all of their prices--we could evaluate their costs and quality in advance and make choices about where we'd seek care if needed.The number of incidents that defy the timely luxury of actually making choices is less than 1% of healthcare demand.We learn, over time, which auto mechanics we can trust. We don't have to review their prices for each and every repair because their prices are the same for all customers and they develop reputations.With real transparency, we'd have the same in healthcare. Competition and smart choices. 99% of healthcare is no different than any other market--unless you want it to be.

Comment: The conditions aboard these vessels would be considered awful to a lot of people.  This does not mean they are slave-like.  Life on a fishing boat is rough.  As a deckhand in Alaska I saw captains performing "galley table surgeries" on a few different occasions.  So much of this rhetoric about conditions on these boats like, "... forced to defacate in buckets..." is just that, rhetoric...and hyperbole.  Furthermore, having worked on over 30 Hawaii longline vessels I would offer from personal experience that never once have I heard a single crew member express a wish to be liberated.  I've heard a lot of grumbling about captains or personal disputes btw other crewmen, but never has anyone even suggested to me that they were there involuntarily. Several of the crew members with whom I maintain a friendship, mostly Phillipino, that I have spoken to regarding this issue of late have expressed fear that they will loose their jobs.  Just a few thoughts to keep perspective.

Comment: It is foolish to paint the past in the colours of the present - it becomes meaningless.  In any event, whatever the sins of our forefathers, there is much to admire about the founding of Canada and the indomitable spirit of all those people who came here and carved a civilization out of wilderness, dealing with a hostile climate, hostile environment and all the rest. For many the experience here was deadly.  Their lives were hard in a way most of us can't imagine today.

And at the same time, so many fought to uphold the principles of culture, civil society and the rule of law.  No human civilization is perfect.  But for the most part, those early Canadians made a good showing of themselves.  And that we are here living this well today is a testament to their efforts.

Comment: Been reading comments to both sides of the issue here, and I guess we must just be unlucky. Those who stayed now have second generation children and, as one commenter said, have multiple vehicles.  In just our general area, we have two homes with 7, two with 5, and two with four.  That's 32 vehicles!  And of course, either 1 or none in the garages which are used for extra rooms.  Then we have a couple of rental homes  with new tenants every year, usually young military couples who love to party, so every weekend add another 4-5 cars.  And even though it's temporary, it adds to the lack of street parking.  Many times we want to leave or come home only to find a car about 1/3 into our driveway.  All fire hydrants are blocked, too.  I guess none are vacation rentals, but that might almost be a relief.

Comment: The political scenes in BC and Alberta are more complex than Gary Mason suggests.

BC has had a stable pattern since the 1941 Provincial election. Henceforth, the Government was held by a formal or informal anti CCF/NDP coalition with rare NDP Government interludes & the periodic rise (and absorption into the aforesaid coalition) of centrist, urban based 3rd Parties. Only Party names change.

The enduring fault-line in Alberta since the 1930s has been between (on the one hand) the urban centred liberal & moderate conservative elements at the forefront in the Progressive Conservative Party & (on the other hand) the more rural, southern Alberta centred social conservative element in Social Credit, the Western Canada Concept & now Wildrose.

Arguably, BC’s pattern is more stable (but with the NDP in the ascendency) as Alberta’s centrist & conservative factions splinter along the aforesaid fault-line in response to changed demographics.

Comment: The proposal is to enhance the taxation of investment income in a corporation by eliminating the refundable element of the corporate investment tax. 

Basically, when a corporation earns business income it will pay a low rate of tax, so it will start out with more to invest than would a shareholder if the income was issued as a dividend and invested. When the corporation earns investment income, however, this income is taxed at a special high rate (not the regular corporate rate) that is designed to be the same tax rate that an individual would pay on the same investment income. 

The way the law works currently is that a part of this special high tax is refunded when a corporation pays dividends to shareholders. The proposed change is to eliminate the refund, so this income will essentially be taxed twice (once at the high corporate rate and then again as a dividend in the shareholder's hands) which should mimic what would have happened if the shareholder invested it personally.

Comment: Most of my family has lived inQuebec since 1957.  We are allophones (ie not from English backgrounds, but English speaking).  Since the election of Mr. Couillard,  my family reports that never have things been so peaceful in Quebec. Fewer strikes.  Balanced (or soon to be balanced) budget.  The sovereignty strife all but gone (it was always there before, even under the Liberals).  

Though things are not necessarily better for the non-Francophone elements of Quebec society.  Just as the French decades ago decried discrimination against them by the English, the tables have now been turned and they are doing the same (a human nature thing, sadly).  The language police (Bill 101 enforcers) are still out there, and so forth.

But even so, there's mostly peace, a vibrant cultural scene, and a sense that Quebec will finally stop being a 'have-not' province.  There will always be a fault line. But the nation remains whole.

Comment: Icon:  The Civil Conversation platform incorporates peer review to filter out "uncivil" comments.  If one of our posts is deleted it's because other commenters, upon reviewing it, found it unacceptable.  I think the system is working well with far fewer trolling comments and better focus on the issues at hand. 

The "live" staff at the RG or at the CC site, as I understand the system, only review posts which have been "flagged" by readers for specific and excessive incivility.  I think the system is a big step up from Disqus which often got mired down in the exchange of very nasty ad hominem attacks.

The use of peer review and the associated algorithms which support the platform are very new and are still being improved upon.  I have emailed several concerns and suggestions to the group of folks who have developed the system and have found them very receptive to ideas and concerns.  If you have issues, share them with the CC folks.  I've found them both open and appreciative, gary..

Comment: Google and Facebook have been collecting your data from their inception, typically with unknowing permission of their users who did not read or understand the implications of the lengthy legal terms and conditions for use of their "free" products. Now people will be just as unknowingly willing to give up their data, but will be paying their internet provider to take it! Microsoft and Apple could start offering trustworthy VPN services, but would have to be careful to allow other competitors equal access. I would choose Apple, given that choice, since they have a long held company policy of encrypting all customer data residing on their servers while leaving the only copy of the encryption key on your device. Apple could not give away your data even if they wanted to. They backed this up by refusing to help the FBI crack the San Bernardino terrorist's iPhone. Any other VPN provider would require serious vetting.

Comment: Dr. Collins' assertion that "we do everything possible to avoid the creation of unnecessary pain" does not reflect the reality of experimentation on animals. Species ranging from nonhuman primates, dogs, and rabbits to mice and rats are subjected to painful procedures without the benefit of pain medication. In traumatic brain injury studies, which inflict excruciating head injuries on mice, most published studies do not list any form of analgesia. When pain medication is given, it is often insufficient. For example, in sepsis experiments, where abdominal surgeries are performed to induce severe infections, mice may be given just one dose of post-surgical analgesia, which is woefully inadequate for the agony of this condition. Pain management protocols often consider the convenience of the experimenters above the animal's discomfort. Sadly, the current oversight system that Dr. Collins praises so highly fails in its mandate to protect animals from unnecessary pain and suffering.

Comment: Mr. Picard is perhaps unfamiliar with the fallacy of equivocation (misleading using of a term with multiple meanings). 'Chocolate' can refer to the product of the plant Theobroma cacao and it is used in common parlance to refer to candy (i.e., 'chocolate bars'), but the two are obviously not the same thing. The nutritional scientists recommending the health benefits of chocolate (e.g., using organic cacao powder in food preparation or eating a few squares of dark chocolate with +80 cacao solids) are obviously not urging the consumption of Mars bars. An equivalent argument would be to claim that chicken is a poor source of protein because of KFC.

Comment: Not all the blame, but a fair share more than what you suggest. I hope that the board members were as well informed of problems, issues, and performance of the KSD as you are and have presented. Excellent! That being said, the board has both the mandate and the forum to speak out on behalf of the community and the students and they have been woefully silent. I have an understanding for resolving differences quietly, at the lowest level, and privately, but not as the sole method. Members of the board should have been long ago vocal when things started going wrong, pick any of the problems you've pointed out. They have a fiduciary responsibility towards to students and sound public education. They have fallen well short. They haven't performed well enough, regardless of who might be primarily responsible for any of these problems. Hardly worth having a publicly anointed board to monitor  school policy and programs if they collectively or individually choose to sit on their hands.
